result.story:
A pink drink served in a Martini glass and called The Cosmopolitan is said to have originated in San Francisco in the 1980s, but it wasn't
until 1988--the year Absolut Citron was launched--that the
Cosmopolitan as it is known today was created. Bartender Toby Cecchini
adapted the original recipe, using fresh juice, orange liqueur, a
splash of cranberry, and the first citrus-flavored vodka. The rest is history!
result.name: Absolut Cosmopolitan
result.descriptionPlain: Fill a shaker with ice cubes. Add all ingredients. Shake and strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with orange.

result.story: For some reason, drink history isn't as well documented as mathematic formulae or Canadian history. The origin of the Bloody Mary is disputed, but our story -- and we'll stick to it -- is that it was invented at The New York Bar in Paris in the early 20s. Might it be the winning color that has kept it in style, ever since?
result.name: Absolut Bloody Mary
result.descriptionPlain: Stir all ingredients in a mixing glass. Pour into a highball glass filled with ice cubes. Garnish with celery and lemon.

result.story: "It has been widely reported that the Bellini got its start in Harry’s Bar in Venice, Italy. That was 70 years ago, and today it’s one of the most classic drinks around. To make peach purée, peel and slice peaches (remove pit; plant pit in backyard) and run through a food processor with simple syrup to taste."
result.name: Absolut Bellini
result.descriptionPlain: Add Absolut Vodka and peach puree into a chilled champagne glass. Top up with champagne.

result.story: The drink was created in 1915 at the New York Bar in Paris - later Harry's New York Bar - by barman Harry MacElhone. The combination was said to have such a kick that it felt like being shelled with the powerful French 75mm field gun, also called a "75 Cocktail", or "Soixante Quinze" in French. The French 75 was popularized in America at the Stork Club in New York.
result.name: French 75
result.descriptionPlain: Fill a shaker with ice cubes. Add gin, lemon juice and simple syrup. Shake and strain into a chilled champagne glass. Top up with champagne. Garnish with lemon.

[Top up|Action|topup] with [soda water|Ingredient|soda-water].
result.story: Cuba is the undisputed birthplace of the Mojito, although the exact origin of this classic cocktail is the subject of debate. One story traces the Mojito to the 16th century when the cocktail was known as “El Draque,” in honor (or dishonor) of the English pirate and slave-trader Francis Drake.
result.name: Mojito
result.descriptionPlain: Muddle mint leaf and simple syrup in a highball glass. Fill with crushed ice. Add light rum and lime juice. Stir. Top up with soda water.

result.story: In 1962, the Universidad del Cuyo published a story which cited a Peruvian newspaper called El Comercio de Iquique as indicating that Eliott Stubb created the "whisky sour" in 1872. El Comercio de Iquique was published by Modesto Molina between 1874 and 1879. However, the oldest historical mention of a whisky sour prepared in the world comes from a newspaper published in Wisconsin in 1870. As the gin sour has historical references dating to the 1860s, the Peruvian whiskey sour origin is spurious.
result.name: Whiskey Sour

result.story: There are many rumors about its origins. It was supposedly created at the time of the wedding of Princess Mary and Viscount Lascelles, in London, in 1922. However, the drama critic and Algonquin Round Table member Alexander Woollcott claimed that it was named after him. Other stories say it was named after the Russian tsar, Alexander II.
result.name: Brandy Alexander
result.descriptionPlain: Fill a shaker with ice cubes. Add cognac, dark cacao liqueur and cream. Shake and strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Add nutmeg.

result.description: [Stir|Action|stir] [irish whiskey|Ingredient|irish-whiskey], [brown sugar|Ingredient|brown-sugar] and [coffee|Ingredient|coffee] in a [wine glass|Glass|wine-glass]. [Float|Action|float] [cream|Ingredient|cream].
result.story: Although different variations of coffee cocktails pre-date the now-classic Irish coffee by at least 100 years, the original Irish coffee was according to sources invented and named by Joe Sheridan, a head chef at Foynes, County Limerick but originally from Castlederg, County Tyrone. Foynes' port was the precursor to Shannon International Airport in the west of Ireland; the coffee was conceived after a group of American passengers disembarked from a Pan Am flying boat on a miserable winter evening in the 1940s. Sheridan added whiskey to the coffee to warm the passengers. After the passengers asked if they were being served Brazilian coffee, Sheridan told them it was "Irish coffee".
result.name: Irish Coffee
result.descriptionPlain: Stir irish whiskey, brown sugar and coffee in a wine glass. Float cream.
